posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: Hello, I have recently been elected as my team’s new mechanical lead and am looking for a comprehensive yet manageable manufacturing challenge to refresh my current team members’ proficiency with our commonly used tools. Our team frequently utilizes a miter saw, band saw, drill press/drill, lathe, taps, and essential tools like wrenches and screwdrivers. If anyone has any suggestions or insights from their experiences, I would greatly appreciate it! Thanks!

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked: Not sure if you can make it with your schedule or before AP tests start, but my team wants to add an L1 ground intake system to our extra drive train. If there's space in your algae shooter, let me know—I think it could be a fun mechanical challenge!

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: To be honest, I like well-considered ideas. However, given our current resources and future plans during the off-season, I'm considering making it one or two smaller projects that don't involve our robot or building a new one. We might explore something similar then, but likely not right away. I'll definitely remember that. Thanks!

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: Using CAD software, we plan to design a complete robot from a past game that addresses mechanisms we haven't constructed recently, followed by constructing parts of it during practice sessions.

Hm, this is precisely what I’d suggest. I’m assuming you’ve built an elevator due to this year’s game—if not, that’s an incredibly vital subsystem to perfect. Alternatively, maybe install your elevator onto a strong pivot based on 2023—a fantastic project for an add-on to a subsystem you’re familiar with. Especially noting that the extending pivoting arm is such an incredibly potent archetype.

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked:
The text is:


actually this was our robot this year and we in the end didn’t even include the telescoping arm on the back so some sort of cascading elevator/ chain elevator is definitely on our offseason list. (we built telescoping arms 3 years in a row now) However with your mention of the pivot for an elevator or a pivot in general that is something we have had trouble with making robust in the past so if you have any suggestions for that too it would be greatly appreciated!

**Cleaned-up version:** This was our robot this year, but unfortunately, we didn’t include the telescoping arm on the back. A cascading elevator or chain elevator is definitely on our offseason improvement list. (We’ve built telescoping arms for three straight years now.) Additionally, regarding your mention of pivots for elevators—something we’ve struggled with making robust in the past—if you have any suggestions, we’d appreciate it greatly!

My dear, an algae shooter isn't exactly a fire robot. In 2023, many excellent robotic designs, such as the 148 and 6329, stand out as highly effective mechanisms. However, if you're already skilled with telescopes, you might not need them. Instead, consider building a sturdy pivot, like the 2910 arm, by adding just one extra subsystem. This approach can create a very competitive robotic design. While telescopes and elevators both provide similar functions, experimenting with different rigging methods, like chain/string or cascade systems, could enhance your builds. For detailed guidance on constructing a reliable pivot, visit [this page](https://www.frcdesign.org/mechanism-examples/pivots/2910_2023_pivot/) on FRCDesign.org.

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: we do find stability issues in our telescoping arm so something chain based or string based may be significantly better but I would also still like have the larger chain based elevator down especially with the prospect of larger recycle rush like game pieces in the future

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: An example of the type of project I'm looking for is something from my rookie year where our leads made little clamps from a C-channel and a bolt by cutting them down, then drilling and tapping a hole on top. We analyzed their accuracy in size and straightness after tapping. It was small and simple, serving as a good refresher on those tools, but I'd like more complexity and involve more tools.

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: It is extremely important to ensure that both our new members and the team are well-prepared for the upcoming build season. As we approach recruitment season, I am working on constructing the curriculum for our new members, aiming to excite them about the upcoming season and prepare them adequately for future challenges.

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked:
What type of equipment do you have available?

I think it is beneficial to split training into two tracks: mechanical CAD/design and mechanical fabrication. There is an abundance of resources for mechanical CAD/design, such as FRCDesign.org. However, mechanical fabrication will need to be tailored to the capabilities at your workspace. Training to design things that you can actually manufacture (or outsource to sponsors/etc) called “design for manufacture” needs to be considered.

For instance, we have quite a capable manufacturing facility and our kids tend to design parts for cutting our fiber laser for everything “because it’s fast and easy” despite being the incorrect approach. This fall they will be learning to use the lathe and vertical mill by making a spring-loaded tap follower. They’ll learn to read prints, use a caliper and micrometer, and assemble something, on top of basic mill and turn operations.

Don’t neglect designing and fabrication for electrical components, too.

What we did was use multiple workshops, each focusing on a distinct topic. Day 1 covered basic tool usage under close supervision—riveters, drills, small hand tools, and simple tabletop machines. On Day 2, we introduced strategic design, allowing students to discuss and draw their ideas until reaching a consensus. Day 3 marked the start of the capstone project, involving team assignments across various components, including wiring and programming. Day 4 featured presentations and testing of completed shooters. Day 5 included cross-training between electrical and mechanical teams. This approach provides new students with hands-on experience in mechanical design and strategic planning ahead of the season.

posts.name: Jacob Waiser
posts.cooked: Our design and mechanical fabrication subteams have been divided into two groups focused on different aspects of training. One group specializes in ideas for fabrication while noting that our mechanical fabrication team also includes electrical expertise. I plan to discuss some of the recommendations with our design lead. In terms of fabrication tools, our team frequently utilizes the miter saw, band saw, lathe, drill press, rivet gun, hand tap, and various hand tools such as drills and saws.
